docs.snippet: Gene Kelly, the dancer, actor, director and choreographer who brought a vigorous athleticism, casual grace and an earthy masculinity to the high romance of lavish Hollywood musicals, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gene Kelly, the dancer, actor, director and choreographer who brought a vigorous athleticism, casual grace and an earthy masculinity to the high romance of lavish Hollywood musicals, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83. His longtime publicity agent, Warren Cowan, said Mr. Kelly had never fully recovered from strokes he suffered in 1994 and last year.

headline.main: Gene Kelly, Dancer of Vigor and Grace, Dies

docs.snippet: Antonia's Line," the Netherlands' official candidate for this year's best foreign-language film Oscar, unfolds as a work of magical feminism. With the tone of a fable and the lulling bucolic look of a pastoral fantasy, it tells of  one strong woma...
docs.lead_paragraph: Antonia's Line," the Netherlands' official candidate for this year's best foreign-language film Oscar, unfolds as a work of magical feminism. With the tone of a fable and the lulling bucolic look of a pastoral fantasy, it tells of one strong woman and her talented descendants, all blessed with self-sufficiency and remarkably little need for men in their lives. Indeed, the fact that the sturdy, formidable Antonia (Willeke van Ammelrooy) perpetuates her bloodline at all becomes one of the film's more fanciful little miracles. As written and directed with quirky charm by Marleen Gorris, whose earlier "Broken Mirrors" and "A Question of Silence" were much more strident, "Antonia's Line" begins and ends on the day of Antonia's death. As with magical realism, there is a certainty that the natural world will cooperate with the characters' sense of certitude, and it does.

headline.main: A Line of Strong Women With Faith in Destiny

docs.snippet: Italy emerged from a three-week Government crisis today with a surprise choice as Prime Minister-designate and a vague pledge by major political parties to push through difficult constitutional reforms.         Heading off early elections, Preside...
docs.lead_paragraph: Italy emerged from a three-week Government crisis today with a surprise choice as Prime Minister-designate and a vague pledge by major political parties to push through difficult constitutional reforms. Heading off early elections, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro today appointed Antonio Maccanico, a 71-year-old former cabinet minister and longtime civil servant, to head Italy's 55th postwar government, succeeding Lamberto Dini, who resigned after one year in office.

headline.main: Italy Turns to Top Bureaucrat To Try to Remake the Country

docs.snippet: He isn't D. Wayne Lukas, who has won the last five Triple Crown races with three different horses. And he isn't Bill Mott, who has won 12 races in a row with the one and only Cigar. He is Frank Passero Jr., king of the claimers, who  bounced into ...
docs.lead_paragraph: He isn't D. Wayne Lukas, who has won the last five Triple Crown races with three different horses. And he isn't Bill Mott, who has won 12 races in a row with the one and only Cigar. He is Frank Passero Jr., king of the claimers, who bounced into the winner's circle in his bold yellow jacket twice today at Gulfstream Park after saddling 10 winners in 10 races over the last nine days. Because of the shifting way that racing records are kept at small and large tracks on both sides of the border, nobody was certain that Passero had set a record. As his winning streak kept growing, researchers kept coming up with the names of other trainers who had gone on a roll in the past: Robert Hilton won nine straight at Charles Town in 1980, Oscar Barrera at Aqueduct in 1983, Alex Bankuti at Fort Erie in Canada in 1984 and Chris Englehart at Finger Lakes in 1989.

headline.main: King of the Claimers Wins 10th in a Row

docs.snippet: Best Pal, the third-leading money winner in thoroughbred racing history, was  retired at the age of 8 yesterday with the promise that he would spend the rest  of his life in leisure at the Golden Eagle Farm in California, where he was born and bre...
docs.lead_paragraph: Best Pal, the third-leading money winner in thoroughbred racing history, was retired at the age of 8 yesterday with the promise that he would spend the rest of his life in leisure at the Golden Eagle Farm in California, where he was born and bred. As one of the most durable horses in modern racing, Best Pal competed for nearly six years, won 18 of his 47 races, including six Grade I stakes, and ended his career with earnings of $5.6 million. The only horses who earned more were Alysheba, with $6.6 million, and John Henry, with $6.5 million.

headline.main: Best Pal Gets to Retire After Making Millions
